questions.text: Cancer-'The emperor of all maladies spares no one'. Which of the following is the most common childhood malignancy?
questions.solution:
Leukemias are the most common childhood malignancies. Among these, acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is the most common, accounting for about 77% of childhood leukemias. 

Most commons in childhood malignancies:

  • Second most common malignancy in childhood: Brain tumor
  • Third most common malignancy in children: Lymphoma
  • Most common solid tumor in children: Brain tumor

questions.text: You are asked to review an article titled, 'Childhood cancers- a menace'. Which of the following statements is wrong and needs to be edited out?

choices.text: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia is the most common type of leukemia in children with Down syndrome.
The most common intra-abdominal malignancy is Wilm’s tumor.
The most common extracranial solid malignancy is neuroblastoma.
The most common brain tumors in children are infratentorial.

questions.solution:
The most common intraabdominal malignancy in children is neuroblastoma. 

  • The most common leukemias seen in Down’s syndrome: acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) > acute myeloid leukemia (AML)
  • The most common site of a brain tumor in children: Infratentorium
  • The most common extra-cranial solid neoplasm in children: Neuroblastoma
  • The most common intra-abdominal neoplasm in children: Neuroblastoma
  • The most common primary neoplasm of renal tissue in children: Wilm’s tumor

questions.text: What is the most common leukemia you would encounter in a child with the following findings?
questions.solution:
The image shows a typical Down's facies (flattened nose, flat occiput, low set ears, protruding tongue). The most common leukemia in children with Down syndrome is acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).

Children with Down syndrome are at increased risk of both acute lymphoid leukemia (ALL) and acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

10% of neonates with Down's syndrome develop transient leukemia or myeloproliferative disorder. These features usually resolve within the first 3 months of life. However, they require close follow-up, because 20–30% will develop typical leukemia (often acute megakaryocytic leukemia) by 3 years of life.

Note:

  • Most common leukemia in Down's syndrome: B-cell Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (overall)
  • The most common leukemia in children <3years of age with Down syndrome is acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
  • Most common AML in Down's syndrome: M7/megakaryoblastic

questions.text:
Jeevit, a 7-year-old boy brought to you by his mother, complains of bone pain so severe that he cannot sleep. Investigations reveal:

Leukocyte count: 16,000 cells/mm3

Hemoglobin: 6 g/dl

Platelet count: 60,000 cells/mm3

Peripheral smear shows numerous immature blast cells and is suggestive of acute lymphoblastic leukemia

In this age group, which immunophenotype of ALL is most commonly encountered?
questions.solution:
B-lymphoblastic leukemia(pre-B-ALL) is the most common immunophenotype with TdT+,HLA DR+, CD10+, CD19+, CD20+, CD24+, Cy Ig + , with onset at 1-10 years of age.

The most common type of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) in children is B-lymphoblastic leukemia (previously termed pre-B-ALL)

Based on current WHO classification: The most common subtype of ALL is B lymphoblastic leukemia > T lymphoblastic leukemia > Mature B-cell Leukemia (Burkitt leukemia)

The production of symptoms and signs of ALL is a result of the replacement of bone marrow by malignant cells and caused by secondary bone marrow failure. On physical examination, findings of pallor, listlessness, purpuric/petechial skin lesions, or mucous membrane hemorrhage can reflect bone marrow failure. The proliferative nature of the disease may be manifested as lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, or, less often, hepatomegaly. At presentation 75% of patients have leukocyte counts of <20,000/µL; thrombocytopenia is seen in 75% of patients and hepatosplenomegaly in 30–40% of patients. Patients with joint pain may have evidence of joint swelling and effusion. Deep bone pain may be present with marrow involvement, but tenderness will not be elicited.

questions.text:
You are posted in the pediatric hematology department as a first-year postgraduate. All of the following cases you encounter are at an increased risk of developing leukemias except:

Case 1: A 2-year-old child with neurofibromatosis type 1

Case 2: A 4-year-old with Fanconi syndrome

Case 3: A 1-year-old with ataxia-telangiectasia

Case 4: A 3-year-old with severe combined immunodeficiency

Case 5: A 10-month old with pernicious anemia
questions.solution:
Fanconi’s anemia (not syndrome) predisposes to the development of childhood leukemias eg: B-ALL due to defective DNA repair. Fanconi syndrome is a syndrome of inadequate reabsorption in the proximal renal tubules. Congenital pernicious anemia does not predispose to leukemias.

Factors predisposing to childhood leukemias

  • Genetic conditions:
    • Fanconi’s anemia
    • Bloom syndrome
    • Ataxia telangiectasia
    • Li-Fraumeni syndrome
    • Down syndrome
    • Severe combined immunodeficiency
    • Neurofibromatosis 1   
    • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
    • Diamond-Blackfan anemia
    • Schwachman diamond syndrome
    • Kostmann syndrome
  • Environmental factors:
    • Ionizing radiation
    • Alkylating agents
    • Nitrosoureas
    • Epipodophyllotoxin
    • Benzene exposure
    • Advanced maternal age.

Chronic lymphoid leukemia is associated with warm and cold types of autoimmune hemolytic anemia.

questions.text: To diagnose a 5-year-old child with acute lymphoblastic leukemia, a pathologist has to see at least ____ percentage of blast cells in a bone marrow biopsy.
questions.solution:
The lower cut-off percentage for diagnosing acute lymphoblastic leukemia on bone marrow biopsy is 25%. 

Unlike with myeloid leukemias, there is no agreed-upon lower limit for the proportion of blasts required to establish a diagnosis of lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). In general, the diagnosis should be avoided when there are < 20% blasts. 

The image below shows numerous lymphoblasts seen on a peripheral smear.

Work-up of ALL:

It is important that all studies necessary to confirm a diagnosis and adequately classify the type of leukemia be performed, including bone marrow aspiration and biopsy, flow cytometry, cytogenetics, and molecular studies. The initial evaluation should also include a CSF examination. If lymphoblasts are found and the CSF leukocyte count is elevated, overt CNS or meningeal leukemia is present. This finding reflects a poorer stage and indicates the need for additional CNS and systemic therapies.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child who was being evaluated for pancytopenia is diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Which of the following findings would indicate a poor prognosis?

choices.text: Minimal residual disease>0.01% at the end of induction therapy

questions.solution:
MRD(Minimal residual disease) is a quantitative estimate of the burden of leukemic cells present in marrow. MRD>0.01%at the end of induction suggests a poorer prognosis.

Initial WBC count of <50,000cells/mm3, B-cell immunophenotype and t(12,21) indicate a standard risk(Favourable prognosis)

Risk-directed therapy is the standard of current ALL treatment and accounts for:

  • Age at diagnosis
  • Initial WBC count
  • Immunophenotypic and cytogenetic characteristics of blast populations
  • The rapidity of early treatment response (i.e., how quickly the leukemic cells can be cleared from the marrow or peripheral blood)
  • Assessment of MRD at the end of induction therapy.

The poor outcome of Philadelphia chromosome-positive ALL with t(9;22) has been dramatically changed by the addition of imatinib to an intensive chemotherapy backbone.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is rushed to the casualty due to difficulty in breathing and swelling of the face and neck. Clinically, he has features suggestive of superior vena cava obstruction. Chest X-ray image shows superior mediastinal widening. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL) is the most likely diagnosis since the chest X-ray shows superior mediastinal widening- indicating an involvement of the thymus gland.

T-ALL accounts for about 15% of childhood ALL cases; it is more common in adolescents - this is the time when the thymus reaches maximum size.

60% of patients with T-ALL present with a mediastinal mass. The mediastinal mass may be asymptomatic and detected only on chest x-ray or may cause cough and dyspnea, particularly on lying flat or with facial swelling and plethora due to vascular compression (superior vena cava syndrome).

B-ALL presents usually between 1-10 years of age perhaps because the number of normal bone marrow pre-B-cells (the cell of origin) is greatest very early in life.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant with seizures and failure to thrive has cutaneous nodules and hepatosplenomegaly. On investigations, CBC reveals hyperleukocytosis with a leukocyte count of 1,10,000cells/mm3. Peripheral smear and immunophenotyping studies reveal large, irregular lymphoblasts, with a phenotype negative for the CD10 (common ALL antigen) marker. On a cytogenetic study which of the following is most likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
The above findings are diagnostic of Infantile acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Translocation (4;11) involving the MLL gene is most commonly associated with Infantile leukemia accounts for the very high relapse rate.

2% of cases of leukemia during childhood occur before the age of 1 year and are referred to as infantile leukemia.

Patients often present with hyperleukocytosis and extensive tissue infiltration producing organomegaly. Subcutaneous nodules, known as leukemia cutis, caused by infiltration by leukemic cells are observed more often in infants than in older children. 

The leukemic cell morphology is usually that of large, irregular lymphoblasts, with a phenotype negative for the CD10 (common ALL antigen) marker (pro-B), unlike most older children with B-ALL, who are CD10 +. Has a very poor prognosis.

Note:

Infants with AML present with CNS and skin involvement and most commonly have a subtype known as acute myelomonocytic leukemia.

questions.text: A mother has noticed recently that her child refuses to be touched, seems to be in distress, and cries inconsolably. She brings her child to you who was investigated thoroughly and was diagnosed to have acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat her?
questions.solution:
L-asparaginase is used in the treatment of acute lymphoid leukaemia (ALL). ALL can present with hepatosplenomegaly, severe joint and bone pains that the kid refuses to be handled.

It is observed that some lymphoid malignancies are unable to synthesize asparagine on their own and must derive it from the bloodstream. L-asparaginase catalyses circulating L-asparagine, thereby inhibiting protein synthesis in the cancer cells.

Treatment of ALL

  • Induction: 4 weeks
    • L-asparaginase: single dose (side effects: pancreatitis, thrombosis)
    • Vincristine: weekly (side effects: neuropathy, SIADH)
    • Prednisolone
    • Anthracycline
  • CNS prophylaxis- intrathecal methotrexate
  • Consolidation: 
    • Methotrexate
    • Epipodophyllotoxin
    • Cyclophosphamide
    • Cytosine-Arabinoside
  • Maintenance: 24-36 months
    • 6-Mercaptopurine
    • Methotrexate

Other options:

  • Imatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor used to treat chronic myeloid leukemia and acute lymphoblastic leukemia with t(9;22) BCR-ABL fusion gene.
  • Tretinoin is used in acute promyelocytic leukaemia with t(15;17) PML-RARA fusion gene.
  • Cladribine is used in hairy cell leukaemia.

questions.text: You are posted in the hematology department as a pathologist.  You are asked to report the bone marrow biopsy slide given below, which belongs to a 3-year-old child who is being evaluated for pancytopenia. To make a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia, what percentage of such cells should you visualize at the least?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is confirmed by the presence of more than 20% myeloblast cells (as shown in the image) in the bone marrow.

Flow cytometry and special stains can be used to identify myeloperoxidase-containing cells, which confirms the myelogenous origin of leukemia.

Note:

The diagnosis of acute lymphoid leukemia (ALL) requires the presence of more than 25% blasts in the bone marrow.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy was brought to the pediatric OPD with complaints of persistent fever for the past 1 week. His CBC is given below:

Hemoglobin: 5.1 g/dL

Leukocyte count: 1,40,000 cells/mm3 

Platelet count: 12,000 cells/mm3

A review of peripheral smear confirms acute myeloid leukemia. Which of the following cytogenetic findings would indicate a poor prognosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Monosomy 7 is associated with a poor prognosis in patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

The production of symptoms and signs of AML is a result of the replacement of bone marrow by malignant cells and caused by secondary bone marrow failure-pallor, fatigue, exercise intolerance, bruising, oral mucosal bleeding, or epistaxis, as well as fever, which may be caused by infection or the disease.

In addition, patients with AML present with signs and symptoms that are uncommon in Acute lymphoblastic leukemia, including subcutaneous nodules or“blueberry muffin” lesions (especially in infants), infiltration of the gingiva (especially in monocytic subtypes), signs and laboratory findings of disseminated intravascular coagulation (especially indicative of acute promyelocytic leukemia), and discrete masses, known as chloromas or granulocytic sarcomas.

Prognostic implications of chromosomal abnormalities in AML are given below:

Favorable prognosis
  • t(8;21); RUNX1-RUNX1T1
  • Inv(16) or t(16;16); CBFβ
  • NPM1 mutation
  • CEBPA mutation

Poor prognosis
  • inv(3) 
  • t(6;9)
  • 5q-
  • del(7q)
  • complex karyotype (≥3 abnormalities)
  • Monosomy7

questions.text: A child with a violaceous, raised nodular skin lesion which on biopsy is found to be infiltrated by myeloblasts is likely suffering from which type of Acute myeloid leukemia (AML)?
questions.solution:
Nodular, violaceous skin lesion infiltrated with myeloblasts is descriptive of Chloroma otherwise known as extramedullary myeloblastoma or granulocytic(myeloid) sarcoma. Myeloid sarcomas are seen in AML subtypes M2, M4, M5a, and M5b.

“Chloroma” was coined due to the peculiar green color of the tumor caused by myeloperoxidase present in tumor cells.

These masses can occur in the absence of apparent bone marrow involvement and typically are associated with t(8;21) translocation. Chloromas also may be seen in the orbit and epidural space.

The main conditions that can cause bilateral orbital masses in children are idiopathic non granulomatous orbital inflammation, metastatic neuroblastoma, and myeloid sarcoma

questions.text: A neonate with trisomy 21 has anemia, petechiae, hepatosplenomegaly, and no life-threatening complications on examination.CBC reveals high leucocyte count and peripheral smear shows numerous myeloblasts. The genetic makeup of blast cells when studied reveals GATA-1 mutations. At 3 months of age, his CBC counts come back to normal and there are no blast cells in his peripheral smear. As his treating physician, what would you recommend?
questions.solution:
This infant has a transient myeloproliferative disease, which usually resolves spontaneously in the first 3 months of life, and they require close-follow up because 20–30% will develop typical leukemia (acute megakaryocytic leukemia) by 3 years of life.

Approximately 10% of neonates with Down syndrome develop transient leukemia or myeloproliferative disorder characterized by high leukocyte counts, blast cells in the peripheral blood, and associated anemia, thrombocytopenia, and hepatosplenomegaly. These features usually resolve within the first 3 months of life. Although these neonates can require temporary transfusion support, they do not require chemotherapy unless there is evidence of life-threatening complications.

As only 20-30% of such children develop acute megakaryocytic leukemia a bone marrow transplant would be a drastic step in our case.

questions.text: An 18-month-old child presents to the pediatric OPD with complaints of fever and rashes for the past 1 week after extensive workup gets diagnosed as Juvenile chronic myeloid leukemia. Which of the following findings is not consistent with this baby’s diagnosis?

choices.text: The genetic study may reveal NF-1 mutation
The presence of Philadelphia chromosome on FISH
The bone marrow shows a myelodysplastic pattern with <20% blasts.
The peripheral smear reveals nucleated RBCs

questions.solution:
Patients with juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia do not have the Philadelphia chromosome.

Formerly termed juvenile chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), it is a clonal proliferation of hematopoietic stem cells that typically affects children younger than 2 years of age. Patients with JMML present with rashes, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and hemorrhagic manifestations.

Patients with this disease do not have the Philadelphia chromosome (the Philadelphia chromosome is characteristic of CML). The peripheral blood smear shows an elevated leukocyte count with increased monocytes, thrombocytopenia, and anemia with the presence of erythroblasts. Bone marrow shows a myelodysplastic pattern, with blasts accounting for <20% of cells. Patients with neurofibromatosis type 1 and Noonan syndrome have a predilection for this type of leukemia.

JMML in the setting of Noonan syndrome is unique, with most patients having a spontaneous resolution.

questions.text: The most common non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in children is _____________.
questions.solution:
Burkitt lymphoma is the most common non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in children under the age of 15 years.

Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) in adults and adolescents (15-19) years, worldwide.

B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL) is the most common childhood malignancy and the most common leukemia in children. (It is not a non-Hodgkin's lymphoma).

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describe the behavior of Non-Hodgkin lymphoma in a 10-year-old child?

choices.text: Is of high grade and aggressive

questions.solution:
In contrast to adult non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL), which is typically indolent, pediatric NHL is usually high-grade and aggressive.

NHL in the pediatric age group has distinct clinical and behavior properties when compared to adults. These include the following:

NHL in adults

NHL in children

Low/intermediate grade

High grade

Dominantly nodal

Extra-nodal

Variable growth fraction

High growth fraction

Poor long-term outcome

Good outcome

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought with complaints of abdominal distension, fatigue, and night sweats for the past 4 months. He also has a 2-month history of postprandial fullness and recurrent non-bilious vomiting. On examination, he is pale, has hepatosplenomegaly and shifting dullness. A CT scan shows mesenteric and retroperitoneal lymph node enlargement. A biopsy specimen of the mesenteric lymph node reveals tumor cells with high mitotic index and starry sky pattern. The cytogenetic study revealed t(8;14).To stage the disease, which of the following systems would you use?
questions.solution:
Retroperitoneal and mesenteric lymphadenopathy with hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, and short duration of disease, point towards a diagnosis of lymphoid neoplasms.The classic translocation of t(8;14) and starry sky appearance with a high mitotic index on HPE point toward a diagnosis of Burkitt lymphoma. Burkitt’s lymphoma is the most common type of Non-Hodgkin lymphoma worldwide. St Jude system of staging is used for staging childhood non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

Disease

System of staging

Hodgkin lymphoma

Ann–Arbor staging

Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma

St Jude(Murphy) staging

Chronic lymphoid leukemia

Rai staging
Binet staging

The current revised staging system used for NHL is the International Pediatric Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma Staging System (IPNHLSS) which reflects our increasing ability to diagnose lower levels of organ involvement with disease. For instance, the older staging system (St. Jude/Murphy classification) did not account for molecular or flow cytometry involvement of bone marrow, which is now reflected in the new system.

questions.text: A lymph node biopsy of a 9-year-old child with cervical lymphadenopathy showed the following picture. The diagnosis is_____.
questions.solution:
In the picture given above, Reed–Sternberg (RS) cells are seen, which is a pathognomonic feature of Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL).

Reed–Sternberg cells are large and either multinucleated or have a bilobed nucleus (thus resembling an "owl's eye" appearance) with prominent eosinophilic inclusion-like nucleoli. The RS cell is clonal in origin and arises from the germinal center B cells but typically has lost most B-cell gene expression and function.

Hodgkin lymphoma encompasses a group of lymphoid neoplasms that typically arise in a signal node or chain of nodes and spread first to anatomically contiguous sites.

WHO classification of Hodgkin lymphoma includes 5 subtypes namely;

  1. Nodular sclerosis
  2. Mixed cellularity
  3. Lymphocyte-rich
  4. Lymphocyte depletion
  5. Nodular lymphocyte predominance

questions.text: A 12- year-old female comes to you with a flu-like illness and left supraclavicular swelling of uncertain nature. Her chest X-ray shows left mediastinal enlargement. CT scan of the chest and abdomen reveals the presence of enlarged lymph nodes in the neck, mediastinum, and liver, and an FDG-PET/CT scan shows multiple scattered consolidation lesions involving also the bones. The diagnosis of classical Hodgkin’s lymphoma, nodular sclerosis subtype, is made on cervical lymph node biopsy. According to Ann-Arbor's staging system, how will you stage her disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes Hodgkin’s lymphoma with the involvement of liver and bone marrow, which is classified as Stage 4 according to Ann-Arbor staging.

questions.solution:
Age >10 years indicates a poor prognosis in ALL.

Leukocyte count <50,000/mm3, hyperdiploidy, and trisomy of chromosomes 4,10,17 indicate a good prognosis.

questions.text: Sanctuary sites of acute lymphoblastic leukemia are______.
questions.solution:
Both CNS and testis are considered as sanctuary sites of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).

  • A sanctuary site is an area of the body that is poorly penetrated by pharmacological agents and, therefore, serves as a place in which tumor cells or infectious organisms can escape the effects of drug therapy.
  • Early institution of CNS prophylaxis (intrathecal methotrexate) is essential to eradicate these escaped leukemic cells.
  • Testicular involvement is rarely evident at diagnosis, testicular involvement can present as painless testicular enlargement.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with pancytopenia and hepatosplenomegaly. Bony tenderness is also present. He is most likely suffering from the following type of ALL_____.
questions.solution:
B-cell lymphoblastic leukemia (L1)

  • This is the most common immunophenotype of acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL) in a child between the ages of 1-10 years.
  • They present with features of bone marrow failure and organ infiltration such as pancytopenia and hepatosplenomegaly, respectively, so B-cell ALL is the most likely diagnosis.
  • Bony tenderness may be present due to sub-periosteal infiltration of lymphoblastic cells.
  • T-cell ALL (L2) typically presents in adolescent boys with a large anterior mediastinal mass (thymus or mediastinal lymph nodes), causing respiratory distress or superior vena cava obstruction.
